got to the institution. That is an absurdity and it was not corrected in this bill, notwithstanding amendments put forward by the opposition.
Maybe the reason was that the government is committed to introducing sentencing reform legislation. In our view that should have been presented before corrections. In terms of time sequence sentencing clearly comes before corrections and parole.
In fact, the cart is before the horse. Sentencing reforms are going to come after corrections reforms. I regret that. The reason for that has never been adequately explained. It might be political, it might be administrative. We do not know. I hope these reforms in sentencing come soon. There are many other areas in terms of sentencing that have to be addressed which the public is concerned about that have not yet been dealt with. I would not want anybody to see the end of this debate and the subsequent vote and think that we had dealt with all the issues of criminal law reform that must be dealt with.
Another item is mandatory supervision, or statutory release as it is now called in the new bill. That is the concept of releasing every single inmate at the two-thirds point of the sentence subject to detention provisions that say that if a person is at a real risk of being a violent re-offender that person can be detained, but the burden is on corrections officials to make a case for detention. If they fail to do so, if they mess up-it is not as though they have never made an administrative error in this field before-or if they fail to adequately make the case, that inmate is out at two-thirds.
That concept of mandatory supervision has validity. As a society we do not want to be in a position in which we have to release an offender cold turkey at the very end of a sentence. It just does not make sense to release somebody into the general population. If we did that, that offender, regardless of the offender's intention, on the first day out would be on the Yonge Street subway sitting next to my kids or my family, my mother or my father. We do not want that. We need a time for integration. However, I question whether the two-thirds point is the appropriate point for that release in every
Government Orders
sentence. This issue may come up in the sentencing reforms. I do not know.
I wonder whether the two-thirds point of a 20-year sentence is the same conceptually as the two-thirds point of a three-year sentence. I simply leave that as a matter that from my point of view has been inadequately responded to in the provisions of this bill.
Another area I wanted to mention, it really was not dealt with in the bill but it is appropriate to mention it, concerns appointments to the National Parole Board.
In Toronto yesterday morning my leader and I met with municipal officials and others in the community, including a representational group from the black community. We had a conversation concerning representation of visible minorities in various institutions. This government is in the process of failing to achieve its commitments made to Canadians to hire and ensure reasonable representation of visible minorities.
It is failing in the area of the National Parole Board. Roughly 20 per cent of the population of offenders are visible minorities. That includes visible minorities of all groups. The percentage of Parole Board members who are visible minorities is 1.6 per cent. That 1.6 per cent figure flies in the face of a 5 to 6 per cent of our general population who are visible minorities, and it is terribly inadequate.
The government and the Parole Board have been failing in an area that is extremely important. I want to bring the government's attention to that issue and will continue to bring the government's attention to it until it gets it right.
The bill does not address the area of young offenders, and I guess the government feels it does not have to address it at this point. This is an area which is partially covered by the Young Offenders Act in terms of how young offenders are dealt with in the corrections system. Young offenders here would have to be in the adult system. They would start at about age 17 or 18 because some young offenders are tried in adult courts.

May 12, 1992
Government Orders
I recently met offenders of that age group in federal institutions and they are looking at life sentences. I feel the corrections administration dealing with young offenders has been inadequate and this bill simply does not deal with that.
I am pleased we were able to get a bill that went this far through. It does make some changes to address perceived needs and real needs. However, most of it involves band-aids and does not go as far as I believe, and many colleagues in the House believe, it should have gone in structurally reforming and addressing changes in the field of corrections and the National Parole Board.

speakeroldname: Mr. Rob Nicholson (Parliamentary Secretary to Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada):
speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am pleased to say a few words on this particular bill because I believe it is an important one and it is a good one.
As was pointed out quite correctly by the speaker for the New Democratic Party, it increases the time that offenders will be spending in jail. It increases the discretion by the judge to increase from the present one-sixth and one-third provisions for day and full parole to half the individual's sentence.
Speakers from the New Democratic Party have made these comments before and they have made them again. They described the Tories as being harsh, being tough, in our efforts to crack down on crime and individuals who commit crime in this country.
The term harsh, describing us, who would bring in provisions that would keep people in prison longer than they presently are, we heard over and over again. I guess I am not too surprised. I heard the same thing when we brought changes to the Young Offenders Act. We increased the penalty for premeditated murder. We increased that within the Young Offenders Act and straightened out, in my opinion, the test for transferring individuals to adult court. Again we were called harsh and without feeling.
One member described how the Tories were not taking into consideration these troubled young people who have committed premeditated murder and we tough, bad Tories are increasing the penalty. We heard it then.
The hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River talks about the gating provisions and the changes that were made in the Dangerous Offenders Act in the
summer of 1986,1 believe, in which we made it possible to keep dangerous offenders in prison for the duration of their sentences. We made those changes. Again we heard that summer the same arguments, primarily from the NDP, about how terrible what we Tories are doing. Again we were talking about the most dangerous elements of society presently detained and this government's concern about some of these individuals not being prepared and being released to the streets.
I heard all this again this morning. I am disappointed. I disagree with it but it does not surprise me.
There are a number of good points in this bill, one of which addresses the question of victims. We have had legislation before increasing the rights and taking into account the concerns and the rights of victims. I was pleased that the Solicitor General in his comments at third reading made reference to that fact. He said: "Many victims have told us that one of their greatest needs is for better access to information about those who have victimized them. This bill provides an entitlement to specified information at their request. Moreover, it ensures that should they wish, their views will be given consideration when conditional release decisions are taken." This is a good idea. This is the direction we should be moving in.
I was talking with one of my constituents not an hour ago who was worried about the position of victims and I told him the truth. I said that we are moving in that direction. The very bill that is being discussed in Parliament this morning takes the victims into account when a decision is being made to release an individual and that is as it should be. That is one of those things the big bad Tories are doing in the criminal justice system.
These are changes that I can live with.
One of the arguments made by some hon. members as to why it is terrible that the Tories are increasing penalties and detaining people longer is: "What is the deterrent value of this? Just look at Washington, D.C. It has lots of crime down there and it has tough penalties".
I suppose if we take that to its logical conclusion, why would we ever be detaining people who have committed premeditated murder? Why do we not take these troubled individuals and send them on their way or do something else for them? Why would we ever bother detaining anybody?
May 12, 1992

I disagree with that whole idea. I believe that part of the role of the Criminal Code and all the legislation in this particular area is to provide a deterrent value. I say that partly from experience and partly from what I think is common sense. I practised law for a number of years. I practised occasionally as a defence lawyer. I talked with individuals, some of them my own clients. I remember one individual who was sentenced. He broke into, I believe, 36 different homes in the city of Thorold, Ontario; breaking and entering. He was 16 or 17 years old, and in those days he did not come within the provisions of the Young Offenders Act, but within the Criminal Code. The Crown attorney proceeded, I believe, on seven or eight. The individual received six months in jail. Before I had my bill into legal aid, I was getting a call from the individual. I said: "Just a minute, I thought you just went to jail". He said, "I am out now".
He is out in four or five weeks and back on the street. I ask you, what kind of a message does that send?
We have penalties. We make provisions within the Criminal Code. We set maximum sentences as guidelines to judges because we are trying to send a signal. We send a signal to society as to what we believe is appropriate conduct and what is inappropriate conduct. There is a deterrent value. The members of the NDP and others will say it does not work for everybody. For some individuals a deterrent does not work.
There are other good reasons to keep those individuals for whom a deterrent does not work in jail. Some of the reasons are for the protection of the public. It was estimated that some of these dangerous and difficult offenders serving long sentences may spend four to five months on average. That was the estimate of the hon. member for the NDP. If a deterrent is not going to work before they commit another crime, it will be a little longer before they get the opportunity again. That is only part of what we are doing in the criminal justice system. We are sending out a signal, not only to people within the criminal justice system, but to law-biding Canadians who must have confidence in the justice system, just as
Government Orders
they must have confidence in the Parliamentary system that we inherited and adapted.
I will tell you what happens when people lose confidence. I read an article about a Latin American country. It said that in the parliament of that particular country, lots of wonderful beautiful speeches were made. It made a very interesting point. The people of that country have no confidence that their parliament can change things. Where were the changes being made? There were all being made out on the streets by means of riots and violence.
If people lose confidence in the British parliamentary system to be able to change their lives, that is where the decisions will be made. It is no different from the criminal justice system. If people lose confidence that the individuals who have violated them and who have violated the norms of society are not punished, if they believe that justice is not done, they will take justice into their own hands.
One of the things that always makes me nervous is when I read in North America and elsewhere of people who style themselves vigilantes, individuals who say they are going to protect their property. The courts will not do it, so they are going to shoot the next person who tries to rob their store. That should send a signal of fear to every law-biding Canadian because that is symptomatic of individuals who are starting to lose confidence that the criminal justice system can protect them.
I would say to hon. members that it is a terrible thing keeping these poor misunderstood individuals locked up a little bit longer. All I have to tell you is that you are right. There are many groups that will disagree very forcefully with what I say. Ask your constituents. Ask your next door neighbours how they feel about it. Can you live with the idea that if somebody victimizes you, your family, your home, your property, your city, these people will be detained within the criminal justice system? Can you live with that? Or will you tell me that I must be to blame if a crime is being committed? The blame should be on me so therefore you would not want to keep some of these individuals more than a few weeks or a few months.

May 12, 1992
Government Orders
I know what the answer is. When I talk with my constituents in Niagara Falls, when I send them surveys and I ask their opinion, they can live with it. They can live with having some relationship between the level of sentence given by the judge and the time spent within the correctional service. I believe they can live with that. There are law-biding Canadians from coast to coast who can live with that. It is important for members to support legislation like this.
I know there are hon. members saying this is not perfect. It is the usual thing, you did not quite get that and you should have done this. I know it is the same thing. I have been involved in over twenty pieces of justice legislation in the last eight years. You always hear that you did not get the timing right, you did not go far enough, you could have done something else.
We are moving in the right direction and that direction is to maintain that confidence within the criminal justice system that is absolutely vital, just as it is for parliamentarians to maintain confidence from the people of Canada that this place too can work, that this place can change people's lives. Once you have lost that, it is all that separates peace from chaos.
If you do not believe me, check into countries in which people do not have any respect for the criminal justice system. Check into countries that have no respect for their parliamentary systems of government or whatever governments they have, and you find there is chaos and that law-biding people say: "Hey, if the system does not work then I am going to protect myself. I had better protect my family. I had better protect my community".
That is why I believe there is something in it for all members of Parliament to support legislation like this. For those hon. members who say: "You did not come in with this next bill and maybe this would have had my support if I could see what you are going to do down the road", we will have lots of legislation in the justice area. All of it will be helping law-biding Canadians. All of it will deal with individuals in a sensitive and constructive manner who get involved with the criminal justice system.
You are seeing it in other pieces of legislation before this House and you will get more. The sooner we move
this one out of this House and over to the Senate, the more opportunity there will be to debate other good pieces of legislation that will be supported by the citizens who live in the ridings of all hon. members.

Mr. Speaker, it is rhetoric at its best. Let us talk some facts. Let us talk facts and not rhetoric.
The hon. member talked about the law-biding members of his community and he talked about the community of Thorold. Let us talk about the community of Thorold and the client that he had who committed some 36 break and enters and how surprised he was when that individual called him again because he was out.
He said: "We bad Tories are being accused of being rough on people because we keep these people in prison and we make them serve their sentence". Let us talk about this client of the hon. member.
He had a provincial sentence of six months and he broke into 36 different homes. Sooner or later, if he continues to offend, he is going to get into what they call the big house, the penitentiary system.
What does this bill from the so-called big, bad Tories do? It says that individual, because he is a first-time offender in the penitentiary system, even though he has broken into 36 or 46 or 56 homes in Thorold, when he gets to one-third of his sentence, he must be released. If he is sentenced to two years in jail, he serves one-third of his sentence and then he must be released, even if the Parole Board believes on the best possible evidence that he is going to go out and steal a few cars in Thorold or that he is going to break into a few more homes and trash a few more homes and scare a few more elderly people.
This is the protection of the public. This is the protection of the law-biding citizen he is talking about. These people must be released.
We are not talking about the National Parole Board looking at the situation and deciding under certain circumstances that this particular person is deserving of being released. These people must be released. The very person he was talking about must be released after serving one-third.
That is in this bill.
May 12, 1992

What about the more dangerous offender that he is talking about? What about those people who commit a series of offences, repeat offenders? They must be released after two-thirds of their sentence.
There is no discretion in the Parole Board. I am not talking here now about the violent offender schedule one, schedule two. I am talking about break and enter artists. I am talking about cat burglars, car thieves, fraud people who defraud elderly citizens of their hard-earned savings. They must be released after two-thirds of their sentence.
How is that the protection of the law-biding citizen, I ask the hon. member?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, Thorold is not in my riding, as wonderful a community as it is. I said the individual was accused of that. He was convicted of, I believe, seven at the time.
That being said, I am glad the hon. member brought up the subject of the National Parole Board.
If there is an institution which I have confidence in within our system it is the National Parole Board. As his colleague, the hon. member for Scarborough-Rouge River pointed out, the decisions overwhelmingly are the right decisions within the confines of the bill.
With respect to dangerous offenders, I do not agree that the individual who continues to commit crimes has to be let out after one-third. That is not what the bill says.
If the hon. member is pointing out inadequacies in other particular points of the bill I would be glad to examine them. He brought up a good point. He said: "I am not talking about dangerous offenders or offences listed within the schedule". Is the hon. member suggesting that he would like to add more? If that is the position of his party let him say so.
The hon. member will remember the trouble that we had during the summer in getting the changes that we did. His party, when it was in power, brought in the bill that offenders must be let out after two-thirds of their sentences. It did not make any difference whether they had stabbed 100 people or if they were in for as many violent crimes as they can count.
We made a change. Maybe I would have liked to have gone farther at the time, but I can tell the member that
Government Orders
we are moving in the right direction in all these areas. Just as on that summer day when we reconvened Parliament to get that particular bill, it is a step in the right direction.
However, it is always the same charge: "It is not perfect", or: "You did not go far enough. This is great but you did not attack the causes of crime".
You didn't have to recall Parliament.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
I can tell you that we have introduced close to 30 pieces of legislation since 1984 in the justice area. This particular bill is in the purview of the Solicitor General for Canada but it deals with the same particular area, the same problems within Canadian society. I believe that every one of them improves the confidence that individuals can have in the Canadian criminal justice system.
I believe that all of them are a step in the right direction. All of them have met with more or less resistance. Some of them went through very quickly with minor changes or minor suggestions, but generally the other parties-his party included-did not like what we were doing in all these areas.
I can tell the hon. member that if this bill gets talked, talked and talked or if the hon. member wants changes at this particular point that cannot be done or should not be done if this bill is to be in place before the summer then he is not being helpful in this whole area that he purports to have concerns about.
If the hon. member wants to give more discretion, put more discretion in the hands of those who are administering or setting penalties and terms for individuals, then support this bill. Put more discretion in the hands of the judges who will be looking at and sentencing these individuals. They are in a pretty good position to be able to evaluate.

Mr. Speaker, the member for Niagara Falls said that there was a crisis in the public perception out there today with respect to confidence in the criminal justice system.
He said that he feels that by getting tougher in the sentencing and the parole system and by keeping them behind bars longer somehow confidence will be restored. I want to remind my hon. colleague from Niagara Falls that after the race riots in Los Angeles just a week or so ago over 7,000 people had to be processed within 48 hours in the court system.

May 12, 1992
I want to ask the member if he thinks that if those 7,000 people were each given a lengthy prison term for what they did-which was illegal, which I do not condone and for which they should pay-there would be no more race riots in the United States, there would be no more riots in the Los Angeles ghettos or in the ghettos of Washington or Chicago? Is that what he is saying? Is that how to restore confidence in the criminal justice system, by throwing them in jail and keeping them there and then ignoring the real causes of crime in society?

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the member makes an interesting argument. Somehow I am supposed to sort out what they are doing in Los Angeles.
I believe very strongly in the criminal justice system as it works in Canada. I have spent the better part of my adult life involved with it. I have confidence in it. I think it works. I think every individual should have a fair trial and all the protections of the British parliamentary system. I have no idea what protections are in place in Los Angeles. I will respond directly to the hon. member's point. He asks: "Do you restore confidence in the justice system by giving lengthy sentences to people who commit crimes?"
I do not know, but I can make a pretty good guess. I can tell the member that if you take 7,000 people who commit crimes during a riot and turn them loose I know for sure that-
I did not say that.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
All right, slap them on the wrist, keep them in for ten days or two weeks. All I can say is that unless you give a sentence that is commensurate in people's minds with the seriousness of the crime, people will lose that confidence.
For the members of the NDP every sentence is a sentence that is too long. It is never quite possible to pin down what the appropriate sentence is.
I never said that either.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
I was not saying that applied only to the member, I am saying it in general about his colleagues.
In terms of what is appropriate for 7,000 individuals who commit crimes in the middle of a riot I am not prepared to say what-

Point of order, Mr. Speaker. The member has just said that the NDP has said that every sentence is too long. Nobody in this party has ever
said that, and I never said that this morning. That is absolutely incorrect.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Justice and Attorney General of Canada
speechtext:
I was referring to the hon. member specifically. However, if there is an example of one sentence that the NDP has thought appropriate in terms of individuals who have committed violent acts, let me know what it was. Generally, in my eight years in this place I have found that whenever the subject of increased penalties was discussed members of the NDP would say: "We are against that", or: "You are not dealing with the right question, you are not asking the right question".
Tell me when and where it is appropriate and I will be glad to listen to it, and probably would support it.

Mr. Speaker, in view of the fact that it is 12.58 p.m., and rather than have the hon. member start his speech and be interrupted by the lunch hour I wonder if there would be a disposition to call it one o'clock.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Youth); Parliamentary Secretary to the Deputy Leader of the Government in the House of Commons; Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of State (Fitness and Amateur Sport)
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I welcome this opportunity to announce the results of a report by the Conference Board of Canada on the high price of dropping out of school in Canada.
The federal "School First" project stresses the importance of a high school diploma if young people are to be successful on the labour market. The same study estimated that 137,000 students who dropped out of high school in 1989 will cost Canada more than $4 billion over their working lifetime in terms of loss of income and productivity and in terms of increased social spending. This is a serious dent in the Canadian economy.
May 12, 1992

According to the report, even a single dropout costs Canadians a lot of money. If Canada, which has a dropout rate of about 30 per cent, were able to bring this rate down to 10 per cent by the year 2000, it would save the economy $30 billion.
Mr. Speaker, this means that young Canadians who decide to stay in school will have made the right choice, for themselves and for all Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, I have received disturbing news from women's centres in Yukon, Quebec and Nova Scotia. Their funding from Secretary of State has been delayed for over six weeks.
The New Democrat government of British Columbia decided to fund women's centres there, but women's centres in other provinces are not as fortunate. Some of these centres operate on less federal funding per year than the Conservative government spends on one newspaper advertisement for the GST. These centres do not have the resources to cover long gaps without funding. They need to pay the rent, the phone bills and the few paid staff they have.
The money has not been forthcoming because of disorganization at Secretary of State. They call it an administrative overhaul. I urge the minister to overcome these problems of poor management and deliver the funding the women's centres need and deserve right now.

Mr. Speaker, two of the victims of the Westray mine disaster are from my riding, Harry MacCallum from Truro and Eric Maclsaac from River Hebert, Nova Scotia. I want to express my deepest sympathy to the families and friends of these men, in fact to all of those involved.
My riding includes Springhill, Nova Scotia, which was the scene of several mining disasters over the years, including those of 1956 and 1958. Even 30 years after the Springhill disasters the pain is still felt every day. This latest tragedy reminds us of the dangers that miners face each day on the job, dangers that very few of us must experience.
Long after the news is over and the world goes on to other issues, the sadness, grief and sense of loss live on. But they do serve to unite these mining communities in a very special and supportive way.

Mr. Speaker, this week is National Tourism Awareness Week. At $26 billion per year, tourism is our third largest industry. It provides employment to over 600,000 people in all regions in Canada.
In the near north alone, which includes my riding of Nipissing, tourism generates over $200 million annually, and $1 billion across all of northern Ontario. In these tough times tourism represents the only hope for many communities. However, even this industry has fallen on some difficulties lately.
The government says that it wants to promote tourism. It has initiated a campaign that in the words of the minister "holds a mirror up to Canada as a tourist distinction".
Let us look at that mirror. The government has increased the tax burden on this industry, which includes a 7 per cent GST, it has cut VIA Rail, it has cut the tourism promotion budget to a miserly amount and it has given us high dollar policies which have discouraged travel to Canada and it has neglected our tourism infrastructure, particularly in smaller communities.
Is it any wonder that Canada's share of the world travel market has been cut in half over the last decade? Yes, I agree with the minister: We should hold a mirror up to Canada, but we should look at this vital industry seriously and not in the rose-coloured glasses that this government views it in.

Mr. Speaker, it is my pleasure today to rise and announce on behalf of the B.C. Waterfowl Society the opening of a new facility at the Reifel Migratory Bird Sanctuary on Westham Island, in my riding of Delta, British Columbia.
The Reifel sanctuary is a very important stop on the Pacific flyway for millions of migratory birds, including the fabulous snow goose from Siberia.
The society has just completed the construction and renovation of a lecture hall, office, gift shop, and the gatehouse at the sanctuary. A significant portion of the resources needed were provided by local donors, including an outstanding bird collection by the Malfet family.
I attended the official opening this past Saturday and was very impressed with the new facilities. I am sure the sanctuary will now be even better equipped to provide for the environmental needs of the community. I commend the Reifel family and the B.C. Waterfowl Society for their vision and commitment.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to take this opportunity to congratulate the Ontario Provincial Police District Nine Traffic Unit from Belleville, Ontario, on being awarded the first national police award for traffic safety. This award was made in recognition of Unit Nine's outstanding efforts to improve safety on Highway 401.
I note that in 1991 we marked another leap forward in the struggle to reduce the fatalities on Canada's roads. A total of 3,654 people were killed in accidents on our highways; indeed, a very large number but the encouraging part is that is the lowest number since 1961.
At a time when the work of police forces across North America is being closely scrutinized and often criticized, it is important we also make the effort to identify those things that are being done right.
I wish to commend the officers in Unit Nine, police across Ontario and Canada, and most important, I praise Canadian drivers for their efforts to make our roads safer. Safe roads save lives.

speakerposition: Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, do you not just love political parties that take credit for government actions while at the same time lambasting the government at every turn. They say we are copying their policy.
A case in point. They are taking credit for an announcement we would not bring in a national publicly financed child care system. I wonder if they took time to read the 1987 report of the special committee on child care. Reference to the report entitled Sharing the Responsibility shows that it still stands as a solid study of the child care issue. It did not recommend a national publicly financed child care system.
I was part of that committee. I know its conclusions are still valid today. These same people now say they would keep the GST and use its proceeds to reduce the deficit and pay down the debt. This is already in legislation. I wonder just who is copying whom.

Mr. Speaker, today is Canada Health Day which presents the opportunity to consider how we can progress farther toward a healthy population. Canadians appreciate our health care system and our concern that it continue to provide the high standard of treatment despite the continuing cuts in the federal share of health costs.
We must also pay more attention to determinants of health which include adequate nutrition, income, housing, and safe working conditions. Today a report on the health of homeless in Toronto shows that not only the homeless are far more prone to conditions such as asthma, bronchitis, and arthritis, but are also subject to severe health outcomes such as mental illness, assaults, and traffic accidents.
On Canada Health Day the federal government must realize that the true cost to the continual eroding of social programs such as social housing, the Canada
May 12, 1992

Assistance Program and the war on child poverty is the health of Canadians.

Mr. Speaker, for the past seven and one-half years the federal government has faced up to the deficit with a series of spending cuts and tax measures, every one of which has been characterized by the NDP as heartless and uncaring.
Now the Saskatchewan NDP government has made an important discovery. Here are some recent selected quotes from Chairman Roy.
If we fail to get the deficit under control we will soon lose the financial freedom to spend what we choose on vital public services.
Deficits are just deferred taxes. The bill has come due.
The important thing is we begin to chew away at the annual budget deficit so we can eventually balance the budget and pay down the principal.
These revelations are lifted right out of federal government budgets since 1985 and recognize both the necessity and the wisdom of federal deficit reduction policies; policies now seen as prudent, realistic, and responsible.
The federal NDP would do well to heed the admonitions of Chairman Roy.

Mr. Speaker, today is Canada Health Day, in a country where our health care system is under siege, driven to its knees by a drought in federal funding. It is no coincidence then that "Your Health, Your Health Care System: Protect Both!" is the theme chosen for today by the Canadian Hospital Association and the Canadian Public Health Association.
Health care is a different reality for each of us. It may be the smile of an exhausted mother in a delivery room, newborn cradled in her arms; the rush of an ER team, pushing a crash cart down a hospital corridor, trying to pump life into a struggling heart; the relief of parents told their son's leukaemia has gone into remission; the
fear of a woman, lump in her breast, waiting for a mammography; the guarantee of a long and independent life for seniors.
Whatever medicare means to you, protect it. It is the most precious right of Canadian citizenship next to democracy itself.
Don't let anyone take medicare away from you.

Mr. Speaker, yesterday morning close to a thousand high school students and staff said yes to Canada. The rally I attended at Georgetown and District High School was called to celebrate and salute Canada's 125th birthday.
Initiated and organized by the students themselves, the event featured our national anthem, stirring words on national unity from senior students, a boost for the Kinsmen's flag-signing tour, and patriotic song.
All this took place in an auditorium covered with red maple leaves and historic national dates, which was the result of a weekend's work.
I would like to congratulate these incredible young Canadians for reminding us of all that is right about this country and to sincerely thank them for including me in this proud and memorable event.

Mr. Speaker, I would like to thank all students at the high school in Georgetown for this magnificent celebration of Canada's 125th anniversary in 1992. These students from my riding said yes to Canada and, especially, yes to Quebec.

Mr. Speaker, this week is National Nurses' Week in Canada.
The Canadian Nurses' Association has proclaimed that this year's theme is Nurses-Partners in Change. Our health care system needs ongoing reform. These changes are best accomplished when nurses are engaged in partnership with others.

May 12, 1992
Oral Questions
Too often in the past, the expertise of nurses has not been adequately recognized. Nurses are ready, willing and able to play a more active role in shaping health policy.
I believe that the contribution of nurses will become increasingly valuable as our health care system is forced to deal with some very serious challenges. On behalf of the Liberal Party, I salute the nurses of Canada for their hard work, dedication and commitment to quality health care.

Mr. Speaker, last week I raised in this House a plea on behalf of the Aksamit family who came to Canada after persecution before the velvet revolution in Czechoslovakia in 1989. They established themselves in Coquitlam, B.C. and put their kids in school in Coquitlam, got jobs. They then were ordered to be returned as not valid refugees.
Yesterday they were thrown out of Canada. It was a horrible scene. The boy, aged 12, was in shock; the young girl was crying. In spite of 200 calls, which is remarkable, to my constituency office the government wouldn't even let the two kids finish school this year. The mother turned to my assistant and she said: "What kind of country is Canada anyway?"
The minister knew. He was not blind-sided. I approached him personally, and I approached the Minister of National Revenue to work on this matter.
I do not do this often, but I rise in this House of Commons and I accuse the minister of immigration of an act of cruelty to these people, and I accuse this government of being blatantly hypocritical when it talks about brighter futures for the world's children.

Mr. Speaker, as Canada's constitutional process moves forward, the issue of Senate reform looms ever larger.
With the most recent recommendation of the Beau-doin-Dobbie report to leave ultimate legislative authority with the House of Commons, the effectiveness of the Senate seems to remain an advisory and reflective function.
In those circumstances, two questions come to my mind: Why should the Senate not be equal; or, why should the Senate not be abolished and be equally zero in all provinces?

Mr. Speaker, the Centennial Cup is the symbol of amateur hockey in Canada. I draw to the attention of this House the achievement of Thunder Bay Fliers this past weekend in winning the Centennial Cup in Winnipeg.
Thanks to the efforts of the coach, David Siciliano, and his staff, the entire team performed outstandingly, and more important, since this is volunteer month, the thousands of volunteer hours contributed by the citizens of Thunder Bay to make this a success.
In particular, I mention the contributions of players Jason Wright, Chris Bums and Mike Figliomeni who all received individual honours from the Centennial Cup committee.
Like everyone in Thunder Bay-Nipigon, we are all proud of the tremendous accomplishments that this team has made to sport in Canada.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I would like to direct a question to the Prime Minister.
Yesterday, I spent the day in Toronto where I met with metro Toronto councillors. Regardless of their party affiliation-some were Tories, some were NDP, some were Liberals-they all said that the present government is ignoring completely the needs of Canada's largest urban centre. They talked to me about the problem of refugee support, infrastructure, law enforcement, housing and drugs. They are terribly preoccupied.
The largest city in Canada was known as "Toronto the good". What is the government doing to make sure that Toronto the good does not become Toronto the good, the bad and the ugly?
May 12, 1992

speakeroldname: Hon. Don Mazankowski (Deputy Prime Minister and Minister of Finance):
speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is indeed unfortunate that the hon. Leader of the Opposition tries to degrade the reputation and the good name of Toronto.
It is one of the finest cities in North America. I think that Torontonians know that and Canadians also know that. Furthermore, this government has taken a number of initiatives in terms of the restructuring at de Havilland to ensure that the aerospace industry has a strong presence there. We have been engaged in the airport redevelopment program. These are all very important initiatives that will not only strengthen the city of Toronto but will indeed provide jobs and economic activity.
In terms of the aerospace industry, he knows that it is a competitive industry. Together with the government of the province of Ontario, de Havilland and Canadair, we have been able to put together-
When was the last time you were in Toronto?

speakerposition: Deputy Prime Minister; Minister of Finance; Vice-President
speechtext:
When was the last time I was in Toronto? About one week ago. I will tell you what I was doing there. We were paying tribute to Laurent Beaudoin, the outstanding leader of Canadair for his leadership, not only in Canada, but internationally.
Toronto citizens paid tribute to him, as they should.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is very nice to visit the big shots but yesterday I met the street kids at a centre called Beat the Street.
I met there a young man of 19 years of age who has been on the streets for seven years. They are there together to try and get off the streets. They are trying to learn, to find jobs, to get a shelter and housing. It is absolutely impossible. They cannot find any part-time jobs for those kids who are on the streets.
I would like to know from this government what it is doing for these people who want to gain back their dignity, the 10,000 kids who are on the streets of Toronto today. They want jobs.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, when the hon. member visited Beat the Street, I hope he recognized that this is a federally funded initiative to meet and help not the big shots but those people on the streets.
Oral Questions
The hon. member refers to the youth of Canada. When he looks at the effort that the Department of Employment and Immigration has made in order to target more relevant assistance to these kids in Canada, the youth of Canada, he will want to correct the statements that were made in this House Friday by members of his party, alleging cuts to these programs for youth when the truth of the matter is that they have been increased.

speakeroldname: Hon. Jean Chretien (Leader of the Opposition):
speechtext: Mr. Speaker, the problem we are discussing is real. Young people have told me, for instance: "What good does it do us if the government spends $21 million on ads on prosperity, when we can't get jobs?"
Hear, hear.

The problem, we have been told, is that some people used to be able to get along on part-time jobs, but now, it is apparently impossible, either in Toronto or any other Canadian city, for them to find even part-time work and be able to live their lives as citizens of this country with at least some dignity.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think it is absolutely astounding that the Liberals should all of a sudden wake up to the problems of Canada's youth, problems we started to address two years ago with our "School First" initiative, which is aimed at encouraging young people to stay in school.
We restructured the Labour Force Development Strategy to give these young people a chance to get the kind of training they need to make a more effective transition from school to the job environment.
Today, the Liberal Party would have us believe there are no programs at all to help these young people. Mr. Speaker, the government has urged provincial governments, the private sector, employers and unions to work together with us to help improve the effectiveness of these programs. He is complaining about unemployment, and I remember in 1984, when I ran for the first time and he was in the government, he wasn't complaining-

I am sorry, but the hon. member for York North has the floor.

May 12, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
By now the Prime Minister must understand that our youth are faced with a serious national crisis, a crisis of opportunity. Overcrowded, underfunded universities are turning our young people away. The economy is shutting them out, the 30 per cent high school drop-out rate is robbing them of a bright future.
How many wake-up calls does the Prime Minister need before he will act?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, it is scary sometimes to sit on this side of the House and watch the opposition slowly but surely wake up and realize that we have a serious drop-out problem.
What the Liberals on the other side do not seem to understand is that first of all, education is a provincial responsibility. Two and a half years ago, we started a massive stay-in-school program, trying to help provincial governments deal with the drop-out problem in Canada.
By the way, the study that the hon. member referred to yesterday was funded by Employment and Immigration with the Conference Board of Canada and aims at doing just that, increasing the level of awareness among Canadians to the importance of reforming our education system.
All I can say to the Liberals is this. Welcome to the challenge. Wake up. Yes, we have a problem.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question for the Prime Minister.
Young people in this country are saying to me that there is a crisis in leadership. They want someone to show them a future, and the present Prime Minister has failed.
Given the serious nature of this national crisis, will the Prime Minister abandon his government's policy of neglect and immediately introduce innovative and effective community-based programs that will give relief to the over 400,000 young unemployed Canadians and the many more thousands who have been denied a rightful opportunity to housing, to training and to education?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, maybe the posturing of the Liberals today would have more credibility if the hon. member came flat out and said: "Yes, we the Liberals were wrong when we laughed and made a mockery of the Prime Minister when he stated that we had a drug problem in Canada".
Now they stand in the House and complain about the problem which they downplayed then. The government recognizes its responsibility in assisting students to reach their full potential, to assist the youth of Canada. The job entry program, for example, runs projects specifically for youth. The objective of this program is to help youth make a successful transition from school to work. More than $122 million has been put into the job entry program this year.
I could go on and list other programs because $400 million of the department's budget is targeted toward youth in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Prime Minister.
Statistics released today indicate that in 1990 the incomes of those people who were working were severely reduced, the worst decline in after-tax income since the Liberal recession of early 1980s.
If the government wants to see the devastating effects of the recession I suggest it look at today's The Montreal Gazette, where some 7,000 people have put in help wanted ads. These range from skilled people, professionals, to carpenters and labourers.
I would like to ask the Prime Minister what his response is to those Montrealers and all those other Canadians across this country who simply want the dignity of the chance to work?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, referring to the article in the The Montreal Gazette, the member is not referring to the job search program that is under-used. Sixty 60 per cent of the members in this job search program are employed within three months.
May 12, 1992

We see big headlines inciting Montrealers-

-to believe that there are no opportunities, when in fact there are. The federal government, through our Labour Force Development Strategy, has increased funds for training Quebec workers to nearly $680 million this year, Mr. Speaker. This is significant funding from which Montrealers, Quebecers and Canadians throughout the country can benefit. So we can try to be gloomy and see only the dark side, but let us look at the strategic investments that the federal government is encouraging in Montreal and there is a glimmer of hope on the horizon.

Mr. Speaker, my supplementary question is for the minister. The minister speaks of economic strategies and strategic investment and I would like to suggest something concrete that this government could do.
If we look at the ads in The Montreal Gazette we find help wanted ads for people who are skilled in welding, engineers, sheet metal workers, carpenters.
I want to ask the minister why this government, why this minister, why the Prime Minister do not invest in these people and put into effect a co-operative municipal infrastructure program that would help the city of Montreal and other cities across this country, that would address the environmental problems and would put people back to work? It would not solve the whole problem but it would certainly help a large number of people.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I often speak about coherence and consistency. Maybe the first thing is that the NDP should reverse its policy of opposing the activation of the developmental use of the money under UI in order to train unemployed Montrealers and Quebecers and Canadians to be able to fill those jobs.
Mr. Speaker, she talks about the help wanted index. An interpretation of that index shows that some 300,000 jobs went unfilled in Canada in 1991. That is why the
Oral Questions
reform of Bill C-21 was so important. We can take this passive money and put it to use to help unemployed Canadians so they can train and obtain those jobs. If this is a change in the position of the NDP I welcome it.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question. The minister is just using bafflegab on all of this. What we are trying to get this government to say is why, in fact, it has not made it possible for people already with training to get jobs. Yes, more training is important, but there has been an increase of 77 per cent in those with post-secondary educations who are unemployed in the last two years.
I say to the minister that-

-according to Statistics Canada, the income of singleparent families headed by women declined the most. Average income dropped over 6 per cent in a year for one-parent families.
Mr. Speaker, what programs will the minister put in place to fight this crisis, especially in terms of job creation, child care services, training for single mothers, and help for poor children? Child poverty has increased 15 per cent.

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, as far as women as a group are concerned, I would remind my dear colleague of the following facts. First of all, some 800,000 more women are on the labour market this month than in September 1984, and 73 per cent of the jobs created for women since 1984 are full-time. This is not the recipe of the Liberals or the socialists in business suits who throw money at the problem for a few months and then put people on unemployment. These are full-time jobs. Mr. Speaker, the hon. member has not congratulated the government on the initiative we just took in New Brunswick. With Premier McKenna, we will target some $200 million on one-parent families, women and the needy. Once again, we will activate passive funds from unemployment insurance and social assistance in order to help these Canadians.

May 12, 1992
Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, the Minister for International Trade stated yesterday that if the United States refuses to allow the softwood dispute to go to the dispute settlement mechanism panel then it would be, and I quote, "a very serious thing."
In fact, it would be more than a serious thing, it would be a violation of the North American free trade agreement.
What exactly does the government intend to do in this specific instance of softwood lumber? Does it intend, in the North American free trade agreement, to seek an improved dispute settlement mechanism?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I do not think it is at all productive to speculate on what might or might not happen if this or that might occur.
I have made it clear what our general response would be, but let us see what the process develops and what the final outcome of the softwood lumber dispute would be. If it is appropriate to go to a dispute settlement panel, we have made it very clear that that would be an option we would take in the event we were not successful.
In the NAFTA, the question of dispute settlement is a matter that is under review to see whether it is appropriate to involve Mexico in the same type of dispute settlement arrangements that we have with United States. That is an objective of the negotiations; to ensure, if it is possible, to improve upon what we have. We will certainly try and do that.

Mr. Speaker, amidst the continuing uncertainties about a North American free trade agreement, Chile, which already has a free trade arrangement with Mexico, is now approaching the United States to enter into the free trade agreement that Canada is negotiating in North America.
Should Canadians assume that we shall enter into free trade with any other country of the western hemisphere
which Washington may decide it wants to do a deal with, or does the government have its own independent trade policy. Do we set out our own priorities with regard to freer trade in the western hemisphere?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International IVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I have enumerated what our trade policy is on a number of occasions. Our number one priority is to get a successful conclusion of the Uruguay round of the multilateral negotiations.
That, as my hon. friend is aware, is in some difficulty right now. As a second track, if you will, we are seeking to expand our access into growing markets. The first opportunity to do that was with the United States with the free trade agreement with our largest trading partner.
The second opportunity to come along is with Mexico, a market that is very promising because of the economic reforms it is has undertaken and the fast growth that is under way in that economy.
If it is appropriate to negotiate further expansions to that, which I think my hon. friend would support, the proposal is to have a broad range of free trade arrangements in the world today. I am not sure if the rest of his caucus supports this position but I understand what his position is.
We are open to discussions with a country like Chile if that is appropriate but right now we have negotiations under way with Mexico and we will continue to try and draw those to a satisfactory conclusion.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, my question is for the minister of industry and international trade.
Last Monday I received a letter from Adriana Schiro, a constituent of mine which says: "I am 23 years old and held a position in the textile industry for over four years. My prospects for maintaining this position are very dim because of the recession, retail bankruptcies, cross-border shopping, GST, but mostly because of the possible free trade deal with Mexico".
She feels betrayed that this country and this government cannot secure her future.
May 12, 1992

Will the minister assure Canadians like Adriana that he will not accept a trade deal that threatens the heart and soul of our textile and clothing industry?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International Trade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, first let me say that my colleague's constituent has expressed a view about the NAFTA negotiations which we share. There is some concern right now that if the proposal that is on the table between Mexico and the United States stands without any changes to reflect the particular concerns and position of Canada, then he is correct and she is correct. It would be unacceptable.
We have been negotiating with our trading partners to see whether we can enhance the position so that the position of the clothing and textile industry under the NAFTA would be even better than it is under the free trade agreement with the United States.

speakerposition: Chief Opposition Whip; Whip of the Liberal Party
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, the Canadian clothing industry says that the agreement as it is now proposed could wipe out this industry with one stroke of the pen.
Can the minister assure Canadians that he will not sign this agreement and that he will protect the textile and clothing industry?

speakeroldname: Hon. Michael Wilson (Minister of Industry, Science and Technology and Minister for International TVade):
speakerposition: Minister for International Trade; Minister of Industry, Science and Technology
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I think I responded to that question in my previous answer. The basis on which we are negotiating with the Americans and the Mexicans is to have a special access to the United States market which would be greater than the access provided under the free trade agreement.
The negotiations are being carried on with full consultation with both the textile industry and the clothing industry to ensure that we are getting the full benefit of their views and understand fully their concerns as to how the negotiations are proceeding.
As I said, I believe it will be possible to demonstrate that we will have a good result here and hopefully a
Oral Questions
result that will be an improvement upon that which we have in the free trade agreement with the United States.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Solicitor General.
The Solicitor General has yet to deny that CSIS or, for that matter before CSIS, the RCMP are using paid informants within registered political parties in Canada.
I would like to ask the minister why CSIS and the RCMP feel the need to spy on registered political parties in this democracy?

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I reject out of hand my hon. friend's allegation that CSIS or the RCMP are spying on registered political parties.
I made the point yesterday in the House. The point was made by the Minister of Justice that the CSIS act precludes any interference with lawful political action or dissent and I can assure my friend that neither CSIS nor the RCMP, as I have been assured by them, is spying on lawfully registered political parties in Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I have a supplementary question. What is the difference between spying and collecting information? How does the minister explain that the collecting of information is not in fact an interference, a direct interference, in the lawful activities of a political party?
Debate.

speakeroldname: Hon. Doug Lewis (Solicitor General of Canada):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I agree with whoever hollered "debate".
If my hon. friend wants to ask a direct question, as he did in his first question, I would be pleased to reply.
CSIS and the RCMP operate under the laws of Canada.
My hon. friend knows that the McDonald commission had a full inquiry. As a result of that we have the CSIS act. For any political party that is involved in lawful political advocacy or dissent there are absolutely no problems and there is no need for any investigation.

Oral Questions

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Employment and Immigration.
The minister will know that the budget for mobility assistance for unemployed workers in western Newfoundland, one of the highest unemployment regions in Canada, has been cut by over 80 per cent over the last two years, from $500,000 to less than $90,000 in mobility assistance in an area where 23 per cent of the work force in unemployed. The result is that unemployed skilled workers available to fill jobs that go unfilled elsewhere in the country remain unemployed, remain unproductive.
Why does the minister of employment have $21 million available for an advertising campaign to advertise the so-called prosperity initiative but no money available to assist skilled unemployed workers to move elsewhere in this country to fill jobs that go unfilled in Canada today?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, if I had had notice of the question, I could have checked into the facts that the member alleges are happening in that part of Newfoundland.
I can assure him of one thing today, and I can do this on the floor of the House. Under that program, if there are qualified workers in that part of Newfoundland and Labrador who need that kind of assistance to fill jobs that are vacant some place, he has my assurance today that the funds will be in place to ensure that.
If the hon. member can point out to me the need there, I am ready to revisit the allocation of these funds and ensure that the people of Newfoundland and Labrador are not penalized because of a lack of funds in this mobility program.

Mr. Speaker, I thank the minister for his answer. I assure the minister that not only have funds been dramatically cut in western Newfoundland, they have been cut in the riding of the member for St. John's East and in the riding of the member for St. John's West. They have been cut in Gander-Grand Falls. They have been cut in Labrador. I have not confirmed it yet but I am awaiting confirmation: they have been cut in all of the regional offices in Atlantic Canada. That is why I assume the minister knew about these cuts.
Can the minister tell the House today then that, if these cuts are in place, they are in place without the
knowledge of the minister, that they do not reflect the policy of the government and that funding levels for mobility assistance in Canada will be restored to the levels experienced two years ago, that is four or five times the amount available today? Will the minister give us that assurance?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I am glad to hear that because if the constituency of the Minister of Fisheries and Oceans has also been cut then he will not accuse me of patronage.
Employment and Immigration is a highly decentralized department. The regional office decides which amounts of money are targeted to different programs according to the needs.
The assurance I have given the hon. member is that if there is a need under the mobility program to help people in Newfoundland and Labrador travel to other areas of Canada to get jobs then I will make the changes so that it is funded.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Minister of Finance.
In response to a question yesterday regarding unemployment in Manitoba, the Minister of Finance argued that his prosperity agenda has been working. However, in Winnipeg alone, at the end of last month we had over 40,000 people actively looking for work.
Could the minister explain, in detail for Winnipegers, exactly how he is about to create 40,000 jobs for these people?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
I suppose, Mr. Speaker, that we could in the Liberal way increase taxes, maybe borrow more, increase the deficit, throw money at the problem or create make-work projects.
Rather we are going to keep on working with the essential features of an economy that creates sustainable jobs. We are going to keep the fundamentals right in the economy. We are going to continue our prosperity initiative. We have asked Canadians to participate in developing an action plan wherein the issues of training, education, the competitiveness of our industrial sectors, learning, taxation and spending will all be looked at in order to provide these people with hope in the future.
May 12, 1992

I do not like the hon. member picturing Manitoba as a waste-basket.

Mr. Speaker, the minister is quite right. Despite his reference, it is not a waste land.
My supplementary question is for the same minister, and I have already given him notice of this question. The minister will know that there has been a great deal of difficulty in getting the aboriginal Pathway Employment Program off the ground in Manitoba.
A coalition of 31 groups, the Winnipeg Pathway steering committee, has approached the minister with a very good solution to the problem. Could the minister indicate to the House whether he is prepared to accept its suggestion to get this program off the ground?

speakeroldname: Hon. Bernard Valcourt (Minister of Employment and Immigration):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, so that colleagues know, Pathway is a program of my department aimed at training aboriginal Canadians to obtain jobs. Some $200 million are targeted to the needs of these Canadians.
Regarding his specific question, I have just received the joint proposal of the Manitoba chiefs and the Manitoba Metis Federation. I will keep in mind the hon. member's comments and those of Mr. Helgason who has been in contact with my office.
In a matter of probably days I should be able to give an answer to that joint proposal and see to it that Pathway serves aboriginal Canadians in Manitoba the way it is serving them all across Canada.

Mr. Speaker, I have a question for the Minister of National Defence.
As we all know, Canadian forces bases such as Gage-town make major contributions to local economies. One major area of this economic contribution is through the continuing transfer process and relocation activities of these bases related to real estate, legal professions, and so on.
I understand that the Department of National Defence has now engaged a master contractor to administer
Oral Questions
all relocation business, that local firms must now pay real estate commissions to that firm, and that the legal business is assigned on a selective basis from that central contractor.
I would like to ask the minister: Is this information correct? If so, what is the role of the DND administration at local CF bases at this time?

speakeroldname: Hon. Marcel Masse (Minister of National Defence):
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I want to thank the hon. member for this excellent question. I can inform him that ERS in Toronto was one of eight companies that bid on the contract. Its bid was accepted because the company was in a position to offer the largest number of services required. These services include putting the homes of members of the forces on the market, the search for a new residence, making travel arrangements in this connection, as well as negotiating legal fees and providing financial advice.
By co-ordinating relocation activities through this firm, the department will save about $10 million.

Mr. Speaker, my question is for the Secretary of State for External Affairs.
Yesterday, in light of the widespread brutality and violence of the Serbian dominated Yugoslav army in Bosnia, violence which is directed at the Croatian and Muslim communities and which has resulted in over 1,300 deaths since February, European Community foreign ministers recalled their ambassadors from Belgrade and demanded the withdrawal now of all Yugoslav troops from Bosnia.
I want to ask the minister: Will she join with the European Community? If she will not show leadership, will she at least join with the European Community in these important steps as well as consider economic sanctions to send the strongest possible message to Belgrade that this widespread violence and bloodshed must end now?

May 12, 1992
Oral Questions

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, I will be releasing a statement shortly on this very topic. We will be joining with the European community in many of the steps that have been taken, except the recall of our ambassador.
I am not at this time prepared to recall the ambassador because we still have some Canadians in the region and we have 1,100 peacekeepers in Yugoslavia and on their way into Yugoslavia.
I want to ensure the channels of communication are kept open to all parties. We have been calling for a peaceful resolution of this for some considerable time. I think for the moment it is important that our ambassador stay there. The European ambassadors obviously are closer to home than ours. I want to make sure we have a capacity on the ground to deal with problems that might arise there.
We have economic sanctions already. They remain in place. They were not lifted earlier when some other countries lifted them. We have been in the forefront of action, calling for an end to the violence and taking strong action where it is needed.

Mr. Speaker, one month ago the minister in a statement said: "The violence must stop immediately. The Serbian led Yugoslav army must be brought under control". That was a month ago and nothing has changed. The killing goes on.
Given the situation of the people in Bosnia who desperately need food and medicine, humanitarian aid such as insulin, I want to ask the minister: Will Canada support the very urgent request by the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees for United Nations troops to protect a humanitarian convoy which will be able to bring in food and medicine to the people of Bosnia?

speakeroldname: Hon. Barbara McDougall (Secretary of State for External Affairs):
speakerposition: Secretary of State for External Affairs
speechtext:
Mr. Speaker, we have supported the UN High Commission for Refugees throughout this entire process. I want to assure the hon. member and the House that we have given $2.3 million worth of humanitarian aid ourselves through various multilateral agencies.
I will of course be looking at the request from the UN High Commission for Refugees on anything additional that is required.

Mr. Speaker, my question is directed to the Prime Minister.
At their recent meeting in Halifax, all federal and provincial representatives agreed to adopt the Beau-doin-Dobbie Committee's constitutional recommendation that guarantees, and I quote: "the vitality and development of the language and culture of French speaking and English speaking minorities throughout Canada."
Can the Prime Minister give the House the assurance that the federal government still maintains this position, this commitment to language minorities?

Mr. Speaker, the government has always defended the interests of language minorities, wherever they happen to be in this country.
At this very moment, the minister is discussing with his colleagues a number of constitutional provisions that could further improve the situation of our minorities.
I have the impression the House will be asked to consider all proposals at the appropriate time, and I think the general position of members will be to offer more assistance to Canada's language minorities.
[English)

Mr. Speaker, will the Prime Minister commit himself to convincing the provincial premiers to adopt the Beau-doin-Dobbie wording on linguistic duality? Will he promise not to sign any agreement which does not include this wording?

Mr. Speaker, I had the pleasure of convincing the provincial premiers twice to sign a unanimous constitutional document whereby they all undertook to do certain things, and even that was not sufficient to bring about a deal.
